docs.abstract: Richard H. Clarida, the Federal Reserve vice chair, said the central bank was monitoring the virus, as worries roiled markets for a second day.
docs.snippet: Richard H. Clarida, the Federal Reserve vice chair, said the central bank was monitoring the virus, as worries roiled markets for a second day.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is watching developments surrounding the deadly coronavirus closely, but a top official on Tuesday signaled that the central bank is not yet ready to act.

headline.main: Fed Official Says Coronavirus Economic Fallout ‘Could Spill Over’
headline.print_headline: Fed Official Says Posture Remains Wait and See

byline.original: By Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport

docs.abstract: The Fed’s vice chair warned that the disruptions “could spill over to the rest of the global economy.”
docs.snippet: The Fed’s vice chair warned that the disruptions “could spill over to the rest of the global economy.”

headline.main: Another Rocky Day in the Markets as the Coronavirus Spreads

docs.abstract: The tech giant said the virus was causing issues with its supply chain, about a week after Apple said it was facing similar problems.
docs.snippet: The tech giant said the virus was causing issues with its supply chain, about a week after Apple said it was facing similar problems.
docs.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft on Wednesday said its sales in the current quarter would be lower than it had previously predicted because of coronavirus-related disruptions in Chinese manufacturing.

headline.main: Microsoft Issues Financial Warning Because of Coronavirus
headline.print_headline: Microsoft Adds Its Warning To Rising Alarm Over Virus

docs.abstract: Outbreaks of the virus outside China have sparked concerns among investors of global economic damage.
docs.snippet: Outbreaks of the virus outside China have sparked concerns among investors of global economic damage.
docs.lead_paragraph: Nervousness about the spreading coronavirus gripped Wall Street again on Wednesday, and an early rise in stock prices gave way to a third day of selling this week.

headline.main: Stocks Fall Again as Coronavirus Spreads
headline.print_headline: Shares Give Up Early Gains to Virus Fears

byline.original: By Kevin Granville and Katie Robertson

docs.abstract: As markets shudder in response to the spread of the coronavirus, some investors are betting you’ll want what these companies make.
docs.snippet: As markets shudder in response to the spread of the coronavirus, some investors are betting you’ll want what these companies make.
docs.lead_paragraph: [This article is part of the developing coronavirus coverage, and may be outdated. Go here for the latest on the coronavirus.]

headline.main: Stocks to Take With You to the Bunker
headline.print_headline: Stocks You Can Take to the Bunker

docs.abstract: There are many eco-conscious steps to take around your tech, says John Schwartz, a climate reporter. Tech can also help us see the scope of climate change.
docs.snippet: There are many eco-conscious steps to take around your tech, says John Schwartz, a climate reporter. Tech can also help us see the scope of climate change.
docs.lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? John Schwartz, a climate reporter, discussed the tech he’s using.

headline.main: Tech’s Environmental Impact and What You Can Do About It
headline.print_headline: Limiting the Environmental Costs of Technology

docs.abstract: The plan includes $1 billion for an affordable housing investment fund as well as an effort to help first-time buyers.
docs.snippet: The plan includes $1 billion for an affordable housing investment fund as well as an effort to help first-time buyers.
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple on Monday announced a $2.5 billion plan to address the housing crisis in California, becoming the latest big tech company to devote money to a problem that local lawmakers and economists believe it helped create.

headline.main: Apple Commits $2.5 Billion to Ease California Housing Crunch
headline.print_headline: Apple’s $2.5 Billion Plan For Housing in California

byline.original: By Jack Nicas, Kevin Granville and Conor Dougherty

docs.abstract: The site’s editorial team, more than 20 journalists, resigned after an instance of what they saw as meddling by G/O Media.
docs.snippet: The site’s editorial team, more than 20 journalists, resigned after an instance of what they saw as meddling by G/O Media.

headline.main: Deadspin’s Last Staff Member Quits. But Deadspin Is Not Dead, the Boss Says.
headline.print_headline: Deadspin Isn’t Dead, Owner Says, as Last Staff Member Signs Off

docs.abstract: The Times’s chief executive attributed a drop in advertising revenue to a turbulent ad market as the company hit a high of 4.9 million subscribers.
docs.snippet: The Times’s chief executive attributed a drop in advertising revenue to a turbulent ad market as the company hit a high of 4.9 million subscribers.
docs.lead_paragraph: Readers continue to shower The New York Times with money. Advertisers, not so much.

headline.main: New York Times Co. Advertising Drops as ‘Turbulence’ Hits Digital Market
headline.print_headline: Times Loses Advertising But Gains Subscribers

docs.abstract: Officials reversed a plan to outlaw the business as the government explores issuing its own e-currency.
docs.snippet: Officials reversed a plan to outlaw the business as the government explores issuing its own e-currency.
docs.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Blockchain is back in Beijing’s good graces.

headline.main: China Gives Digital Currencies a Reprieve as Beijing Warms to Blockchain
headline.print_headline: Beijing, Warming to Blockchain, Gives Digital Currencies a Reprieve
